text: the book of Psalms this evening, Psalm 78. And I'll be looking here at the first eight verses, Psalm 78, verses one through eight. And I'll read the verses of scripture and we'll get into the message this evening, Psalm 78, verses one through eight. I've titled the message tonight, The Generation to Come. And I am thankful that we have an opportunity to influence a future generation, amen. And we had the privilege this evening of seeing a future generation stand here on our platform, of course, in just a couple of Sundays. On October the ninth, we're going to have a teen takeover service in our evening service. And we'll have the opportunity to see a generation between ours and that one, the teenagers. And we'll have the privilege of being able to see them minister and use the talents that God has equipped them with. And that thrills my heart. I am so thankful for a generation to come. Notice what the psalmist says, beginning in verse number one of Psalm 78. Give ear, O my people, to my law. Incline your ears to the words of my mouth. I will open my mouth and a parable I will utter dark sayings of old, which we have heard and known and our fathers have told us. Notice verse number four. We will not hide them from their children, showing to the generation to come the praises of the Lord and his strength and his wonderful works that he hath done. For he established a testimony in Jacob and appointed a law in Israel, which he commanded our fathers that they should make them known to their children, that the generation to come might know them, even the children which should be born, who should arise and declare them to their children, that they might set their hope in God and not forget the works of God, but keep his commandments. It might not be as their fathers, a stubborn and rebellious generation, a generation that set not their heart aright and whose spirit was not steadfast with God. In verse number four, and then again in verse number six, you see that phrase, the generation to come. As I mentioned already, I am thankful for the generation to come. I am also thankful for those that God has equipped and called to work with the future generation. This evening, as we begin to think about the children that were here and singing, of course, we know that we have folks that in our church have served on Sunday mornings, those that serve in our nursery and our children's church ministry. On Wednesday evening, we have our student ministries and we have folks that have responded to the work that God has done in and through their hearts and lives and they have surrendered themselves so that they could be used of God. They've responded to the prompting of the Holy Spirit of God. And I believe that they are serving as of the ability that God has given them. Indeed, I would say this tonight, that it is a blessing to be laborers together with God. And what a joy to have the privilege of serving God together as a team, as a body of believers. A couple of Sunday nights ago, I had the, on Sunday night, we preached the message, many members, but one body. And just how God has equipped each member of the body for his purpose and to fulfill his purpose. And we were mindful of several things on that Sunday evening. And now as we begin to think about the work in the lives of these young people with regard to the generation to come, I would say this evening that we must acknowledge that there is a mighty battle that is taking place for this generation to come. It has always been the case that there is a battle that is raging over a future generation. But as we sit here today on the eve of the month of October in just a few days and 2022, it's hard to believe the year is almost over. But we see that this battle for a future generation, for the generation to come is raging. And we must acknowledge this evening that as we begin to consider the word of God and the responsibility that we have to impact and influence a future generation, we must understand that we have the need to be actively engaged in seeking to influence a future generation. Active engagement is essential, it is imperative. I find this evening as we think about the church family, and obviously we have parents of children that are here that are seeking to influence their children. We have workers in our church that serve in capacities of teaching and assisting and what have you that are seeking to influence a future generation. But the reality is that each and every one of us ought to be engaged in having some level of influence in a future generation, in the generation to come. I want you to consider this evening, as I mentioned, that active engagement is required. I want you to understand that those that are in opposition to God, those that are in opposition to the word of God, they are actively engaged on seeking to reach the next generation. And not reach the next generation like we talk about. We talk about reaching the next generation for the cause of Christ and to influence them with the word of God, but we find that there's a group of people that are on our earth today that are the workers of iniquity, that are false teachers, that are seeking to capture this future generation. They're seeking to indoctrinate them. They're seeking to develop their philosophy and their worldview. And we must be aware of this battle that is raging. I want you to consider this evening, by way of introduction, a couple of quotes. One from the, of course, wicked Nazi dictator Hitler. He said this, "'He alone who owns the youth gains the future.'" Yes, people are following in that exact mindset. "'He alone who owns the youth gains the future.'" Why do you think there's such a battle over schooling? The Department of Education. It is a battle. And you think about the book of Psalms being the Jewish songbook, if you will, and using the hymns and showing to the generation to come the praises of the Lord. They would often sing the hymns as praises to God and as they would sing the hymns as they were praising God and exalting God, they were showing to that generation to come the praises of the Lord and the importance of praising God. Listen, He is worthy of our praise. He indeed reigns. We find that He has revealed Himself throughout His Word by various names that have been ascribed to Him. And we find in so doing that He is revealing certain attributes or characteristics about Himself. And we find that one that I just so appreciate is when He comes to Abram and He says that He is the Lord God Almighty. El Shaddai. And before you ever read of God asking Abraham if anything is too hard for the Lord, we find that God first revealed Himself to Abraham as being El Shaddai, the Lord God Almighty. And He is the Lord God Almighty. He is able to do exceeding abundantly above all that we ask or think. We understand that He is the strong one, the mighty one. El Elyon is one of the names that's given in the Scriptures in speaking about His might and His power. And we begin to think about how we need to influence a generation to come in showing them that our God is mighty. That He's able to do all things. I want to think about this from two perspectives here this evening. When we think about the end of verse number four and consider the wonderful works that He hath done, number one, I would say the first category that we ought to deal with are biblical works. Listen, I'm thankful as you study the Bible that you get to see the mighty works of God. Amen? You study through the Scripture and you begin to see the wonderful works of God starting in the book of Genesis with creation. And you begin to see how that God created everything out of nothing and God spoke and He said and it was done. And you begin to reveal the mighty works of God and you begin to follow the Scriptures and you begin to read of all that God has done and His wonderful works and how through studying the works of God, He is revealing His power, His ability. He's showing to the people who He is and what He is capable of doing. Obviously this evening as we could go around the room and we could have each one within the auditorium this evening share a wonderful work of our God. Biblically speaking. You think about the water that came from the rock. I mean, we could just go on and on and on. I believe this evening that our children need to know what God has done. They need to know the biblical works. They need to know that He is mighty and He's done these things.
